findings.title: Missing Security Header: Strict-Transport-Security
findings.description: HSTS header missing - no protection against SSL stripping
findings.evidence: Header Strict-Transport-Security not found in response headers
findings.poc:
To reproduce:
1. Request GET http://localhost:3000/#
2. Check response headers
3. Observe missing Strict-Transport-Security header
findings.reasoning: JARWIS VERIFIED (90% confidence): The evidence clearly demonstrates the vulnerability as there is no Strict-Transport-Security header in the response. This suggests that the server does not enforce HTTPS encryption, which could lead to man-in-the-middle attacks. The response behavior is consistent with the claimed vulnerability type, and it's unlikely that this is normal application behavior misinterpreted as a vulnerability.

findings.title: Sensitive Data Exposure: Hardcoded password
findings.description: Found 1 instance(s) of Hardcoded password in response. This data should not be exposed in HTTP responses.
findings.poc:
To reproduce:
1. Request GET http://localhost:3000/main.js
2. Search response for pattern: ["\']?(?:password|passwd|pwd|secret|credential)["\...
3. Find sensitive data in response body
findings.reasoning: JARWIS VERIFIED (90% confidence): The evidence clearly shows the hardcoded password 'IamUse***ng' in the main.js file, which is a clear indication of sensitive data exposure. The response behavior is consistent with a vulnerability type of sensitive data exposure. There are no SQL errors or XSS reflections, and the sensitive data is indeed exposed.

findings.title: SSRF via url parameter
findings.description: Server-Side Request Forgery detected. The application fetches content from user-supplied URL in parameter 'url'. Internal service data was returned.
findings.evidence:
Payload: http://127.0.0.1
Indicator: Localhost in response
Matched: 127.0.0.1
findings.poc:
Payload: http://127.0.0.1
Parameter: url

To reproduce:
1. Navigate to https://googleads.g.doubleclick.net/pagead/viewthroughconversion/834785397/?random=1767298149147&cv=11&fst=1767298149147&bg=ffffff&guid=ON&async=1&gtm=45be5ca1z8812617389za20gzb812617389zd812617389xea&gcd=13l3l3l3l1l1&dma=0&tag_exp=103116026~103200004~104527906~104528501~104684208~104684211~105391253~115583767~115616985~115938465~115938468~116184927~116184929~116251938~116251940&u_w=1280&u_h=720&url=https%3A%2F%2Fcountrydelight.in%2F&frm=0&tiba=Online%20Milk%20%26%20Grocery%20Delivery%20Early%20Morning%20by%207%20AM%2C%20Everyday%20%40%20Country%20Delight&hn=www.googleadservices.com&npa=0&pscdl=noapi&uaa=x86&uab=64&uafvl=Chromium%3B143.0.7499.4%7CNot%2520A(Brand%3B24.0.0.0&uamb=0&uam=&uap=Windows&uapv=10.0&uaw=0&_tu=CA&rfmt=3&fmt=4
2. Set parameter 'url' to 'http://127.0.0.1'
3. Observe internal service data in response
findings.reasoning: JARWIS VERIFIED (90% confidence): The evidence clearly demonstrates a SSRF (Server-Side Request Forgery) vulnerability, as the response contains an HTTP/1.1 200 OK status code and the URL parameter is used to inject a local IP address (127.0.0.1). This is consistent with the claimed vulnerability type.

findings.title: SSRF via callback parameter
findings.description: Server-Side Request Forgery detected. The application fetches content from user-supplied URL in parameter 'callback'. Internal service data was returned.
findings.evidence:
Payload: http://127.0.0.1
Indicator: Localhost in response
Matched: 127.0.0.1
findings.poc:
Payload: http://127.0.0.1
Parameter: callback

To reproduce:
1. Navigate to https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/js?client=google-maps-embed&paint_origin=&libraries=geometry,search&v=weekly&loading=async&language=en&region=in&callback=onApiLoad
2. Set parameter 'callback' to 'http://127.0.0.1'
3. Observe internal service data in response
findings.reasoning: JARWIS VERIFIED (80% confidence): The finding demonstrates SSRF via callback parameter as the 'callback' parameter is set to a local IP address (http://127.0.0.1). The API response clearly indicates that this is not a valid JSONP callback name, which suggests the presence of an SSRF vulnerability.
